subject: Re: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?
msgSnippet: ... I guess you mean never, rather than slow, eh? :) ... I m not sure that s true. If there are only one or two, then we can manage that; but if there are
messageBody:
Bill de h√ìra wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > I admit that, in the case of the classloader fix, the JUnit leaders are
> > being unnecessarily slow. Let me see whether I can do something about
> that.
>
> Slow? I don't think that's the issue!

I guess you mean "never," rather than "slow," eh? :)

> > How many such fixes are there, though, really? There's the classloader
> > fix, and the string compares fix, and other than that, everything else
> > is merely an extension, isn't it? (I'm talking about DbUnit, HtmlUnit,
> > HttpUnit, XMLUnit, ...)
>
> How many is a red herring.

I'm not sure that's true. If there are only one or two, then we can
manage that; but if there are ten or twenty, then it becomes more
obvious that we need to do something.

<snip />
> > Ant is also huge and complicated, compared to JUnit.
>
> And has more uses. And yet, I have no more wrapper code for Ant than
> I have for JUnit. But you're talking technology and features here;
> I'm talking about how to manage and maintain an open source project.

OK. This is probably a blind alley, so I'll stop. :)
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
